name: Anonymous
com:
/vst/ is a place to discuss all types of strategy video games, including both turn-based and real-time strategy, turn-based and real-time tactics, single-player and multi-player (including MOBAs). All platforms are welcome.

Does this mean discussion of strategy games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vst/ is just a separate board specifically focused on strategy games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vst/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

>>1282306
You can also go Tropico way, at least the OG:
You ARE an insignificant power on the global scale, and you don't even matter regionally in most cases. The whole point is to not get squashed by either superpower and also try playing a big game locally.
So the US and USSR are less than some giant blobs on the map and more about NOT getting them into your own playground in the direct, concrete way.
Of course that removes the global scale of things and makes the game more about scenarios, something that the mentioned already Terminal Conflict did. And it wasn't exactly a good solution, especially since it put the situation on its head, as you are either US or USSR fighting a proxy.

It comes down to "first in best dressed": whoever gets there first establishes the alliance. The minor nations, in this case, reach the requirements quicker: theyre Germanic culture, they have a friendly attitude boost, they can increase relations quicker (perhaps by their Advisor) and/or probably have a high diplomatic reputation; so they can fasttrack meeting the "Form Alliance" as compared to Poland or Spain.
Also, take into account who their Rivals ally with as it reduces the ability to meet the "Form Alliance" requirements as well.

is a grand STRATEGY GAME that I have been developing, it's not "off-topic", even if it isn't complete.
Set in pseudo-Europe and inspired by Imperator, it seeks not to be another map painter but an empire manager, with a focus on:
>resource management (you need wood to build ships, grain to feed pops, wool to prevent them from freezing, etc)
>pop management (who all have their wealth)
>character management
>closed economy with prepaid-model
>anti-omniscience (limited information, e.g. you don't know many troops other countries have)
>faction management (all characters belong to a faction, and everything you do impact the faction's loyalty, if you go to war against the faction's beloved country, they might revolt against you)
>army management (army depletes as you advance because you have to leave troops behind to garrison)
>making the world evolve (you turn forests into farmlands, build bridges over rivers, convert villages to cities)

>>1281259
part 2/2
Avoiding the civil wars is easy enough. First read what the party likes/dislikes. They have 2 inherent to the party and 1 extra that comes from the party leader. Make sure to do the positives and avoid the negatives, so you keep a really high loyalty. Next make sure to assign at least one of them as a general, this general is gonna need to win a lot. The more they win, the more loyal their party becomes, losses decrease this though. Next be sure to occasionally use political actions to favor that party, such as promoting one of their members. You can also use the map feature (the compose under the minimap), to see what political parties own which provinces. Parties can only own whole provinces (unless you only control part of one, in which case they own all that you own there). Fully conquer one of these provinces and use an edict that gives them loyalty
Of course this mostly works for just 1 party, if you have multiple parties it requires juggling each one. Usually the more powerful factions are balanced by having to manage more parties

>>1275974
The game is obtuse, and not in the fun way. I've lost track how many times I've accidentally started to promote Confucian values, just because the buttons are poorly align and you will start the top-most action instead of closing the window.
The combat system is a complete fucking joke. As long as you army has at least 10k people with 10k rifles and max training, there is no fucking way you will lose - and those things can be achieved in less than 3 turns.
You can almost entirely ignore the whole political system, it does fuck-all and you will never be betrayed or backstabbed as long as you hire internally (which is also way fucking cheaper than doing it from outside forces). And the only reason you want to recruit people at all is to fill up gaps and/or you overextend yourself and lack now action points to govern your shit. Which is rarely an issue, unless your main character lacks specific specialisation, which almost never happens.
UI is so-so. It's not bad completely, but it constantly blocks itself, buttons overlap and you generally need to do a fuckload of clicking to get some vital info/action.
All of this could be still ignored, if not the fact the game operates on scenario basis and the only "sandbox" that gives you whole China severely limits your choice of factions and characters, which in turn means all the fun stuff can't be played on "global" scale.
Short for the theme, the game has nothing going for itself, and the development pace is abysmal, even for a single dev indie studio. Clocked exactly 115 minutes on it (average scenario can be finished in less than 10) and returned it. Then used another account and checked it for another 100 minutes few months later and it barely moved forward.
Theme is spot-on, the gameplay is barely there.

>>1276141
I've barely played Cities Skylines but apparently there are no wealth distinctions? That's a core part of SC4, it's hard to imagine the game without it. In Simcity you NEED R$ to plow your fields and work your factories, R$$$ are useless stupid richfags who do nothing but sit in their stupid useless richfag mansions and whine while paying less taxes.
The layout of your city changes depending on what services are provided, so you can have low-density, high-wealth suburbs with fully funded schools and hospitals and parks, and low-wealth high-density slums with none of that and no roads next to heavy industry. It isn't linear level-up, and in fact low-wealth is often more useful.

But at the same time Simcity 4 is a grid game. I tried to recreate Sapporo because it's the one city in Japan that was built as a modern planned city and there are good maps of the city layout. This worked to a point. The problem is that the city center may be a grid, but the outlying districts shift the grid 45 degrees, and SC4 is just not designed to handle that. You can't even build diagonal streets in the unmodded game, though you can build roads. Buildings don't grow in at angles, either, not unless you download ones that do. You can't build diagonal bridges either. It really isn't designed for cities that aren't laid out at perfect right angles. If I were playing CS or another game with spline roads I wouldn't have this problem.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Could someone sum up the combat in this game? I dropped it after an hour because it seemed like the combat would be extremly basic and repetitive (I suppose it's all just dealing with Action Points while using various weapons with only either range, damage or AP cost changing and maybe some simple mechanics like Healing, Lockpicking, basic AoE explosives, no? BG came out a year before this game)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1277517
it's an armed conflict so yes, primarily combat will be shooting guns
but there's a bit more than just that, if you can be bothered with it

if you have a strong and athletic sim, you can take chances on running up to enemies and knocking them out with hand-to-hand combat
if you knock out an enemy, you can steal the weapon he's holding (enemies don't always drop the weapon after dying but you can always try to steal it off them as long as they have it equipped)

when a fight in a sector starts but before the enemy actually spots you (not equivalent with turn-based mode being used), you will be in a stealthier "low awareness" mode. enemies will have a slightly less effective field of view, will generally walk or stand around rather than run, and are easier to get one-hit stealth kills on (especially with throwing knives)
some sectors are more rewarding to complete by doing them stealthily, for example in one of the sectors in Alma, you can get a special weapon if the alarm isn't raised

also, if you slip away from a sector without alerting or otherwise being spotted by the enemy, it doesn't count as a battle, so you won't lose team morale for doing so. you can use this for example to try slipping through town sectors without engaging enemies

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1280454
As allies, you have access to snipers and mortars from the get-go, and your infantry, in general, is superior in terms of health and firepower and doesn't suffer from mp drain as badly as axis units, with the exception of UKF. The UC can kite endlessly with proper micro to stay out of range of fausts and, if upgraded with an mg or flamethrower, will require an ambush from shreks or be forced back by an AT gun. AP ammo isn't available until vet 1, so unless you are face charging into mgs it shouldn't even be an issue, and using it means axis has fewer munitions for snares or weapon upgrades which are the only things keeping grens viable when compared to allied inf. Unless the wher player is opting to start with double mgs and pioneers, you should at most be facing 1 pioneer, 1 gren, and a mg 42 team at the start of the round. All of them are fairly fragile if caught out of position and will likely arrive after you if you rush fuel. The early and late game are where wher is the weakest, especially in team games, due to how badly they are affected by attrition.
